**Okay, this seems like the appropriate place to state this and put an end to the speculation:**

Our commitment as your forum moderators is something we take very seriously. And often we find ourselves in unfamiliar territory and dealing with things which there are actions which are required but we do not take any pleasure in doing. For the last few posts there have been some statements of a speculative nature made which others are ***assigning*** meaning to which, to be quite honest, is not helpful and is actually harmful to the forum community. With this in mind, I would like to bring the following to mind: 

1. Every moderator sings a non-disclosure agreement (<abbr title="Non-Disclosure Agreement">NDA</abbr>). They are on file with Squad and it's parent company, Take-Two.
2. When we say that we cannot talk about certain moderation issues, we **mean we cannot do it because of the <abbr title="Non-Disclosure Agreement">NDA</abbr> we signed.** And as with any contract, there are consequences that happen if we break the <abbr title="Non-Disclosure Agreement">NDA</abbr>. We enjoy what we do because it allows us to give back to the KSP community. So, please respect our efforts and accept it when we tell you we can't discuss certain things.
3. Do not badger the moderation team or fuel random speculation based on when we have to tell you *sorry, we cannot comment on \_\_\_\_ at this time*. Doing so only adds to tensions about certain aspects of moderation, forum management, and moderator-forum user relations. While **Forum Guideline 3** does offer general guidance. Particularly,

- **3.3 Open discussion of staff decisions:** *Do not openly discuss action (or inaction) taken by the staff (bans, warnings etc.). If you have concerns about a moderator action, see 3.4 below.*
- **3** **.4 Contesting moderation action:**  *All of the moderators are active community members who try to set a good example and apply the rules as appropriately as possible, but they are only human and can make mistakes from time to time. If you disagree with something they have done, please contact them or a senior moderator privately, and the issue will be re-examined.*

That's it. If you disagree with a moderator's action, the rules are clear. Don't openly discuss it in the open on any thread. Do it in a private message. We will be more than happy to discuss an individual moderating issue which you are a party to in a private message. Please do not think of this as a personal invitation to talk about *any* moderation action you are interested in. If it does not involve you directly then we **cannot and will not discuss it with you**.  

So, please, after this post, no further speculation on moderator actions involving banning forum members, banning forum members who happen to be moderators, speculation about such moderation actions, promoting such speculation as fact, or pressuring moderators to provide you answers which run afoul of our non-disclosure agreement (<abbr title="Non-Disclosure Agreement">NDA</abbr>) can and probably will be met with an official warning under Forum Rule 3.3 and/or Forum Rule 3.4.

Thank you for your cooperation and help in keeping our forum operating smoothly and inviting to fans of Kerbal Space Program and Kerbal Space Program 2 of all ages!

> > > 7 hours ago, Fraston said: > > > Not like it matters, but does it take up a name change slot? > > > > 7 hours ago, 5thHorseman said: > > > Does that use up their one and only name change? > No, it doesn't. Rationale: - A user is allowed to request a name change exactly once. The reason for that is to prevent user abuse by hopping names around a lot, which would make life confusing for forum members and a hassle for the moderators. - However, if *we* are the ones forcing them to change their name because we believe it to be inappropriate, then that's on us, not them. So we generally give them the benefit of the doubt by not having that count against their one name change.

We also don't talk about other moderators for the same reason we don't talk about our interactions with forum members: it would be rude. 

Anyway, does anyone have questions about the forum?

In spite of the forum members screaming gloom and doom about KSP and KSP2, I think there's a lot of life in the original if for some reason, KSP2 never becomes a reality or goes to become the blockbuster video game release of 2021!. The original KSP is very mod-able, it's pretty stable now, and you can virtually play it any way you want to play a game about space exploration - largely thanks to the modding community and the excellent support and attention given to the community by [@SQUAD](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/66485-squad/). It's a combination which rarely happens in the computer gaming industry. There are always going to be really great and long-played "cult pc games" out there; KSP is one of them. I've been playing since 2011 and it is my "go to" game. ![:wub:](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_wub.png ":wub:")
